text: Return on Tangible Common Equity (ROTCE) was 15%.
CET1 capital ratios were 15.0% for both Standardized and Advanced.
Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity was $514B.
Standardized Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) were $1.7T.
Cash and marketable securities stood at $1.4T.
Average loans were $1.3T.
4Q23 net income was $9.3B and EPS was $3.04.
Excluding significant items, 4Q23 net income was $12.1B, EPS was $3.97 and ROTCE was 19%.
Managed revenue was $39.9B.
Expense was $24.5B and managed overhead ratio was 61%.
Average loans of $1.3T were up 17% YoY and 1% QoQ.
Excluding First Republic, average loans of $1.2T were up 4% YoY and 1% QoQ.
Average deposits of $2.4T were flat YoY and up 1% QoQ.
Excluding First Republic, average deposits of $2.3T were down 3% YoY and up 1% QoQ.
CET1 capital was $251B.
Distributed common dividend of $3.1B or $1.05 per share.
Completed $2.0B of common stock net repurchases.
Net payout for the last twelve months (LTM) was 41%.
Net income (ex. FR) was $4.4B, down 3% YoY.
Revenue (ex. FR) was $17.0B, up 8% YoY, predominantly driven by higher net interest income.
Expense (ex. FR) was $8.7B, up 10% YoY, driven by higher compensation and investments.
Credit costs (ex. FR) were $2.2B, with NCOs of $1.6B up $791mm YoY and a net reserve build of $538mm.
Ex. FR: Average loans were up 6% YoY and 1% QoQ.
Ex. FR: Average deposits were down 8% YoY and 3% QoQ.
Ex. FR: Active mobile customers were up 8% YoY.
Ex. FR: Debit & credit card sales volume was up 7% YoY.
Ex. FR: Client investment assets were up 25% YoY and 9% QoQ.
Net income of $2.5B was down 24% YoY, while revenue of $11.0B was up 3% YoY.
IB revenue of $1.6B was up 13% YoY, driven by higher debt and equity underwriting fees.
Payments revenue of $2.3B was up 10% YoY.
Lending revenue of $150mm was down 54% YoY, driven by mark-to-market losses on hedges.
Markets revenue of $5.8B was up 2% YoY, with Fixed Income up 8% and Equity Markets down 8%.
Securities Services revenue of $1.2B was up 3% YoY.
Expense of $6.8B was up 4% YoY, driven by the timing of revenue-related compensation.
Credit costs were $210mm, consisting of $121mm in NCOs and an $89mm net reserve build.
Net income (ex. FR) was $1.5B, up 4% YoY.
Revenue (ex. FR) was $3.7B, up 7% YoY, driven by higher net interest income.
Expense (ex. FR) was $1.4B, up 9% YoY, driven by an increase in employees and technology investments.
Credit costs (ex. FR) were $269mm, with a net reserve build of $142mm related to commercial real estate valuations.
Average loans (ex. FR) of $242B were up 3% YoY and down 1% QoQ.
Average deposits (ex. FR) of $262B were down 6% YoY and flat QoQ.
Net income (ex. FR) was $925mm, down 18% YoY.
Revenue (ex. FR) of $4.7B was up 2% YoY, driven by higher management fees offset by lower net interest income.
Expense (ex. FR) of $3.4B was up 11% YoY, driven by higher compensation and investments.
AUM of $3.4T and client assets of $5.0T were each up 24% YoY, driven by net inflows and higher market levels.
Average loans (ex. FR) of $215B were up 1% YoY and up 2% QoQ.
Average deposits (ex. FR) of $215B were down 9% YoY but up 7% QoQ.
Revenue (ex. FR) was $1.8B, up $597mm YoY.
Net interest income (ex. FR) was $2.5B, up $1.2B YoY, driven by higher rates and balance sheet mix.
Noninterest revenue (ex. FR) was a net loss of $687mm, compared with a net loss of $115mm in the prior year.
Expense (ex. FR) of $3.4B was up $3.0B YoY, predominantly driven by the FDIC special assessment.
The outlook for 2024 Net Interest Income (NII) excluding Markets is approximately $88 billion.
The forecast assumes 6 rate cuts in 2024, with the Federal Funds target upper bound at 4.0% by year-end.
Rate and repricing dynamics, including deposit repricing and internal migration, are expected to create an $8B headwind.
Balance sheet growth and mix, including loan growth and modest deposit attrition, are expected to contribute $1.5B.
The adjusted expense outlook for 2024 is approximately $90 billion.

Key drivers for 2024 expenses include business-growth-driven hiring, increased technology spending, continued investments in the business (marketing, bankers, advisors), higher market-dependent expenses, and residual inflationary pressures.
The annualization of the First Republic acquisition is expected to result in a significantly lower exit run rate for 2024.
Expect FY2024 net interest income of ~$90B, market dependent.
Expect FY2024 net interest income excluding Markets of ~$88B, market dependent.
Expect FY2024 adjusted expense of ~$90B, market dependent, which excludes Firmwide legal expense.
Expect FY2024 Card Services NCO rate of < 3.50%.
The Firm reviews results on a "managed" basis, a non-GAAP measure that presents revenue on a fully taxable-equivalent basis.
Metrics excluding CIB Markets (NII and NIR) are non-GAAP measures used to assess performance of lending, investing, and deposit-raising activities separate from market volatility.
Fourth-quarter 2023 net income, EPS and ROTCE excluding significant items (FDIC special assessment and net investment securities losses) are non-GAAP financial measures.
Tangible common equity (TCE), return on tangible common equity (ROTCE), and tangible book value per share (TBVPS) are non-GAAP financial measures used to assess the Firm's use of equity.
Adjusted expense and adjusted overhead ratio are non-GAAP financial measures that exclude Firmwide legal expense.
The presentation reflects the Current Expected Credit Losses (CECL) capital transition provisions, with a $2.9B benefit being phased out at 25% per year.
Total excess high-quality liquid assets (HQLA) represent the average eligible unencumbered liquid assets in excess of what is required to meet stress-period cash outflows.
In Q1 2023, allocations of revenue and expense for Merchant Services were discontinued in CCB and retained in CIB.
The 4Q22 prior-period amount for HQLA has been revised to conform with the current presentation's use of end-of-period figures.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements that are based on current beliefs and expectations and are subject to significant risks and uncertainties.
Actual results may differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking statements.
